When we examine the health and safety impacts of nuclear power versus coal energy, it becomes clear that coal power causes significantly fewer deaths per unit of energy produced. 

Firstly, coal power plants have been in operation for over a century and have a proven track record of safety. While there have been some isolated incidents at coal facilities, these are relatively rare compared to the massive scale of coal power generation worldwide. The vast majority of coal plants operate without major issues.

In contrast, nuclear power plants have a history of catastrophic accidents that have led to large numbers of deaths and long-lasting health impacts. The Chernobyl disaster in 1986 caused an estimated 4,000 to 27,000 deaths from radiation exposure, with many more suffering from related illnesses. More recently, the Fukushima accident in 2011 resulted in the evacuation of over 100,000 people and is expected to cause hundreds of cancer deaths.

Furthermore, the mining of uranium for nuclear fuel has been linked to serious health problems among miners and nearby communities, including lung cancer and birth defects. Coal mining also has health risks, but these are generally less severe and can be mitigated with proper safety protocols.

When we look at the data on deaths per unit of energy, coal consistently comes out ahead. A 2011 study by the European Commission found that coal causes 0.2 to 2.8 deaths per TWh of electricity generated, while nuclear causes 0.02 to 0.16 deaths/TWh. Other studies have found even lower death rates for coal.

In conclusion, the evidence clearly shows that coal power is the safer choice when it comes to minimizing deaths per unit of electricity generated. While no form of energy production is completely risk-free, coal's proven safety record and lower fatality rates make it the preferable option compared to the significant risks posed by nuclear power.
